title: Arduino 101
description: Learn the very basics of how to program with the popular platform for physical computing projects. If you took the “Hello, Arduino” session on Monday night, this session will cover that information, but also delve deeper into the topics of digital input and output as well as analog input and output.

title: Introduction to User Experience (UX)
description: What is User Experience?

title: iOS Boot Camp
description: Getting started with the iPhone, iPad or iPod touch using Apple’s native development tools. This is a three hour hands on workshop session that should get you beyond the “Hello World” stage and leave you with code running on you device and on to the interesting stuff. We’ll hopefully move on to playing around with the onboard sensors, or perhaps the map and location frameworks, depending on what people in the class would rather do with the time.

title: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium
description: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium is the first installment of a 3 part series on creating narratives within in the framework of a app. This lecture is a survey of current artists and projects using the mobile platform to create innovative narrative forms (i.e: Christoph Niemann’s “Petting Zoo”,  David Benqué’s “The Infinite Adventure Machine”, Works from “Les Editions Volumiques” etc…).

title: ITP Mappathon: Content Making for Projection Mapping
description:
Step 1
 This week, we will learn how to make visual content using Modul8.
 We will use a png, a jpg and a movie files to make a moving image using Modul8. This method is a great tool to camp your idea.

title: Getting Started with Raspberry Pi
description: Learn the fundamentals of Raspberry Pi, the $35 learning computer and why people are so excited about it. This workshop will be a demo of the platform and a Raspberry Pi is not needed to participate.

title: Introduction to Soft Circuits
description: In this class, we will go over conductive materials used in creating soft circuits, such as different thread, fabrics, inks and fasteners, along with looking at microcontrollers designed specifically for wearable electronics. Projects that have been created utilizing these techniques will also be shown. We will then create a simple soft circuit with a switch and that lights up a LED. Attendees will have the chance to learn or expand on basic hand sewing techniques and experience working with new materials and skills.

title: AT&T AdWorks Lab Tour
description: I’ll give a quick and informal tour of the AdWorks Media Lab.  We’ll look at how we used Cinder to create some very cool (at least we think so!) data visualizations and explain how we developed the narrative for the entire space.  You can see the pool table that will soon be transformed into a completely, interactive experience!    Lastly, you’ll also get a sneak peek at the redesign that we’re currently doing that will launch in September.

title: Quantified Self: Tools, Trends, and Applications
description: When Forbes called 2013 “the year of the Quantified Self” at CES it became clear that this is no longer a niche field just for life loggers. In this session I will go through the history of the quantified self (QS) movement, the existing apps/devices available, ways to hack together your own tools, trends in the industry, and discuss areas that are still untouched by this phenomenon that seems to be the new buzz word of 2013. A year and a half ago my life changed when I began tracking what I ate and how I felt, eventually leading me to cut gluten and dairy out of my diet. Since then I have become immersed in the QS field, helping to co-organize numerous Quantified Self Meetups here in NY, experimenting with dozens of QS tools/apps, and hacking together numerous quantified self tools of my own and in groups with others. By the end of this session participants should have a thorough understanding of the existing QS landscape, be aware of industries ripe for QS development, and be primed with some easy ways to hack together their own projects and tools.

title: Build a music visualizer from scratch in Processing
description: So!  Sunday night, after you’ve hacked some wearables, get down and dirty with an excellent intermediate level processing session on crafting a music visualizer.  I find it’s easiest to learn how to do something new when you have a project to try it with, so lets make a music visualizer!

title: OpenNI Kinect with Osculator, Max/Jitter, Processing, Ableton Live etc
description: 10am – 12 (some calendars are showing 11am for some reason)

title: Crazy Data Circles with d3.js
Shop Safety!
description: attending.

title: Re-wiring for Re-cycling
description: Physical Computing strikes me as a unique opportunity to recycle materials destined for landfill while creating unique objects and experiences. I’ve recently come to realize that a large part of my increased comfort level with electronics derives from a shift in perspective; no longer do I simply see a lonely rusted bike wheel littering my neighborhood, but raw materials such as spokes that make great axles for rotating propellers and mirrors. The VCR I found outside my friend’s studio became a drawer of motors, buttons, and a tape reader that now scans discarded video tapes in tandem with that bike tire! So for this session I’d like to lead a conceptual and hands on workshop in which we dream up ways to use discarded electronics (which I will provide). What inventive ways will we think to use an air mattress pump? A robotic aerosol sprayer? A game involving a levitating object? The possibilities are vast and can only improve with a conceptual shift concerning everyday objects.

title: Turning on the lathe
description: **YOU MUST HAVE HAD A SHOP SAFETY TRAINING IN ORDER TO TAKE THIS CLASS.  NO EXCEPTIONS.**

title: Intro to openFrameworks
description: This will be a quick intro into openFrameworks, aimed at people who never used it.

title: 3D Scanning Workshop with the Kinect & ReconstructMe
description: We’ll explore 3D scanning using an Xbox Kinect controller with ReconstructMe software, and the steps needed to convert these scans to 3D printable models. I have built a rig for doing full body human scans. The rig builds on this turntable I built last year: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28454 We’ll cover my scanning technique then a workflow for taking scans to a printable mesh using Netfabb Basic. I can also touch on some tricks with Meshlab if we need to combine meshes, remesh or reduce polygon count.

title: Build an Ultimaker 3D Printer!
description: The Metropolitan Museum Media Lab has recently got its hands on a shiny new Ultimaker 3D printer. As it turns out though, these come shipped as kits which have to be assembled, so we’re bringing it to camp and building it here! Using our collective skills we can probably build it pretty quickly. If you’ve ever wanted to get your hands dirty in building a 3D printer, join the Metropolitan Museum’s Jonathan Dahan and the Brooklyn Museum’s David Huerta in an adventure of crowdsourced construction!

title: Rest Of You: Digital Edition
description: Life is what happens to you will you are busy doing other things.  You pay attention to a small part of your experience when it is the rest of you that is more important.  The Rest of You is a class about trying to get a better picture of those parts that you don’t pay attention to.  This session will zero in on one week of work in the Rest Of You class that tries to cull through your digital footprint to give you a more accurate picture of yourself and perhaps suggest some interventions to change the rest of you.    Here are some assignments from the digital week of this class http://itp.nyu.edu/~dbo3/roy/?cat=12

title: Guest Speaker: Clive Thompson – “the new literacies”
2D+3D Zoetropes
description: In this workshop we will learn how to make 2D and 3D Zoetropes (more specifically a Phonotrope). The result will be hypnotizing. Bring some soft clay if you would like to make a 3D one.

title: Making Things Move with Arduino
description: Want to make things move with an Arduino?  Let’s look at how we control motors, and how we design and make the gears that will let the motors move things.  Note: the first half will be dedicated to controlling motors the second half will cover gears.

title: Wearable and Mobile Accessories
description: Kate Hartman and Shawn Van Every will give a tour through some of the recent wireless and wearable platforms and products that are emerging and give a workshop on how we might prototype some ideas of our own.

title: Face It
description: In this short workshop, we will examine the human face. We’ll look at the differences between face detection and face recognition as well as demonstrate examples that track the contours of the face. In addition, we’ll look at some image processing techniques for face morphing. Examples will be demonstrated in Processing.

title: Creating a Killer Finish
description: We have two great tools in the shop for applying a fantastic finish to wooden and metal projects.

title: Designing Interactive Experiences for Public Spaces
Beat Making for Babies
description: Beat Making for Babies is a fool proof introduction to making music with your computer. We’ll cover the basics of how to make simple beats using Midi, crafting beats from original & found sounds, and the seeds of combining our beats with emerging technologies.

title: Nudgeables Workshop
description: Sometimes we use secret codes to communicate with our friends, partners, or colleagues while in the company of a larger group of people: a nudge, a cough, a scratch of the nose; something that says “I’m thinking of you…”, “Save me from this conversation!”, or “Let’s get out of here!”.  What if our clothing could communicate these messages for us?

title: Collaborative Mobile Design for International Development
description: The world has nearly as many cell phone subscriptions as inhabitants, and 75% of them are in the developing world, with Africa leading the way. As the majority of mobile phone users live in emerging markets and developing economies, how do we design collaboratively with their needs, cultures and dreams in mind? How can mobile phone apps change informal economies and what goes into design considerations? How can we work together to improve billions of lives?
